title: prince andrew royal navy initiation pictures
story: The young officer was made to take part in a Crossing the Line ceremony to mark the first time he passed the equator as a seaman in 1982.The ritual involved a crew member of HMS Invincible dressing up as Neptune - the God of the Sea - to hold a court where novice sailors are put on trial for their sins.They then receive their punishment of being shaved with pink foam.In a nod to Prince Andrews Royal background, the photos show him sat down on makeshift throne with a cardboard crown placed on his head.Alarmingly, a seaman dressed as the barber is seen approaching the then second-in-line to the throne with a very large meat clever covered in imitation blood.The then 22-year-old Royal offers his neck towards the deadly instrument while the crew look in in amusement.Another snap shows the Duke of York roaring his head off in laughter during the ritual that took place while HMS Invincible sailed home from the Falklands War.The images make up a series of photos sent from the crew of the aircraft carrier to a brother and sister who wrote to them for autographs.The crew not only sent back a filled-in autograph book, with the Royal signing his name Andrew HRH, but also photographs of life on board including the initiation ceremony.They were sent by Lieutenant Commander Brian Prendergast.The images have now been put up for sale through Bosleys Auctioneers of Marlow, Bucks.Bernard Pass, of Bosleys, said: A couple of kids sent off this little autograph book to HMS Invincible for the crew to sign.But they didnt just get the book sent back they also got these photographs and a lovely covering letter from the commander of the aircraft carrier.They are all unpublished photographs taken by crew members rather than an official photographer.There are very amusing photos showing Prince Andrew’s ‘Crossing the Line’ ceremony.One snap that raises an eyebrow shows a man dressed as a barber holding an enormous meat clever and shaving brush but it looks like he is about to cut off the head of the then second-in-line to the throne.Other pictures in the gallery include Andrew in uniform being interviewed, shots of the deck of the ship and one of a Chinook helicopter lifting Sea Harrier jet.During the Falklands War, Prince Andrew risked his life by acting as a decoy to lure Argentine Exocet missiles away from HMS Invincible.He flew a Navy helicopter behind the aircraft carrier to make the missiles swerve towards the helicopter instead of the ship. He also flew on anti-submarine missions and search and rescue operations.The archive is tipped to sell for £200 at Bosleys on July 4.

title: migration big issue eu brexit james forsyth
story: They are acutely aware that for the EU 27 Brexit isn’t the biggest issue on the agenda, migration is.One Government source tells me: “It’ll be a non-event. They’ve far too much to discuss among themselves.”Migration is plunging European politics into crisis again. German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s coalition is threatening to break apart over the issue.While in Italy, the new government is threatening to close its southern border — blocking migrant rescue ships from landing — and open its northern border, encouraging illegal migrants and asylum seekers to head north to Germany and Sweden.So worried is European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker that he is hosting a mini-summit tomorrow to try to find a solution to the migrant crisis which can help save Merkel’s political career.It is tempting to look at the EU in crisis and say that is why the UK is leaving. But this crisis is making it more difficult for Britain to get a reasonable Brexit deal.The European Commission is running the Brexit negotiations.Its priority is in defending the theology of the European Union, rather than finding practical solutions. As one leading figure in the Government laments to me, Brussels’ chief negotiator Michel Barnier “won’t budge off CETA (Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement) with Northern Ireland stuck in the customs union”.This kind of Canada-style free trade deal is regarded by the Government as inadequate.Mrs May and co have long hoped that the member states, nearly all of whose economies would be hurt by such a limited agreement, would intervene at some point and tell the Commission to engage more constructively with the UK. But this is happening all too rarely.One of the reasons is, in the words of one member of the Brexit inner Cabinet: “Only four national capitals are fully across Brexit.”Many of the countries that are most sympathetic to the UK don’t have the capacity to follow all of the issues concerned.Over the past few years, the key to any deal in Europe has been Merkel. She is not now going to ride to Britain’s rescue— as David Cameron found to his cost in the renegotiation.But the German Chancellor could push the Commission towards a slightly more pragmatic approach.However, she is now trying to keep her own governing coalition together, as well as come up with a deal with the French for eurozone reform, leaving next to no time for Brexit.I am told that when Brexit is discussed in meetings she is “visibly distracted”, turning to aides for advice far more frequently than she does on other issues.This situation is one of the many reasons why the Government should have prepared vigorously for no deal: A credible threat to walk away from the table if the Commission didn’t behave in a reasonable fashion would have got the member states’ attention.But Mrs May now must hope the EU can patch together some deal on migration and that the member states begin thinking seriously about what kind of post-Brexit relationship they want with this country.WHEN the Cabinet gathers at Chequers next month to thrash out the UK’s offer to the EU, one of the most contentious issues will be customs.The Brexit inner Cabinet is split between those who favour a so-called “new customs partnership” (NCP) with the EU – which would see the UK continue to apply EU tariffs after Brexit, with companies receiving a rebate if their goods stayed in Britain rather than heading to the continent – and those who advocate Max Fac, which would use technology to minimise border checks.Two Cabinet working groups are trying to find a way to make these ideas work. Neither group has had a decisive breakthrough yet. But I am told the Max Fac one is “not a million miles away” from a solution.The challenge for the PM is to make these plans acceptable to her own side, including David Davis and Liam Fox. One Brexit inner Cabinet member tells me: “She’s got to have David and Liam. If she doesn’t have them, then she has no solution.”Both Davis and Fox support the Max Fac option. But there are influential figures in No10 who remain convinced that NCP is the option to go for. They argue only NCP can help deal with the Irish border issue and get the Government through next month’s crucial Commons votes on the customs union. They warn: “No NCP, no Brexit.”The fear among Brexiteers is Mrs May will use this Chequers meeting to try to push through a modified version of NCP. They fear the reason the whole Cabinet will be present on the second day is to give Mrs May the numbers to do this if the Brexit inner Cabinet remains split on the issue.Doing this, though, would be extremely risky. It would leave Mrs May with a policy that neither her Brexit Secretary nor her International Trade Secretary support.THE Chancellor and the Defence Secretary aren’t just split over how much money the military should get, but what it should be spent on, too.One Cabinet ally of Philip Hammond’s complains that Gavin Williamson wants to “spend the money on uniformed officers when he should be spending it on robotics and the like”.Their view is that this would be a better response to the 21st-century security challenges Britain faces.But in truth, Britain needs both conventional and new, hi-tech forces if it is to respond to the variety of threats now out of there. That is why we MUST spend more on defence.Those close to Williamson point out that if the Government doesn’t increase the defence budget, our status as the leading military spender in Europe – upon which so much of our influence in the world depends – will be under threat as the French and the Germans increase their military budgets.NEXT week, Theresa May will give a speech setting out the Government’s post-Brexit industrial strategy.Key to this must be artificial intelligence, an area where we are one of the leading nations in the world.I understand that the importance of maintaining the UK’s edge in AI is what led to Mrs May accepting Home Secretary Sajid Javid and Digital Secretary Matt Hancock’s argument that visa rules for tech entrepreneurs must be relaxed.The countries that succeed at AI will end up defining this century.So any deal with the EU must preserve the UK’s ability to regulate these industries of the future in a way decided by us, not Brussels.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: royal ascot racegoers pimms day four
story: Glamorous revellers were seen celebrating their winning bets at the races as they toasted glasses of the much-loved summer cocktail on Friday.It was Ascots unofficial Armed Forces day, with concessions for military personnel and volunteers from the Navy, Army and RAF.Guests always look their best each day of the huge racing event but some went the extra mile for the theme, with one woman sporting a Spitfire-style hat.Sarah, Duchess of York was granted a rare privilege when she joined the Queen in her box - and even shared a joke.The invitation appeared to signal that the Duke of Yorks ex-wife had been permanently welcomed back into royal circles.But Sarah did not make it into the carriage procession which, with her Majesty in the lead coach, signals the start of each day at Royal Ascot.As the Queen passed by the duchess was seen curtseying and to aid her balance she held onto the hand of her daughter Princess Beatrice, next to them doffing his top hat was Andrew.Beatrice wore a dress by The Fold and a Sarah Cant hat, while her mother was dressed in a Roland Mouret outfit and a hat by Philip Treacy.Earlier racegoers were quids in after picking the right colour of the Queens hat for the fourth day running, a feat which left the bookies cursing their bad luck.The head of state wore an Angela Kelly ensemble, a grass green wool coat worn with a dress embroidered with summer flowers and a matching hat.Former England footballer Michael Owen was among the famous faces invited to present prizes to the winning jockeys, owners and trainers.In the racing, David Elsworth and Silvestre de Sousa combined to land the Duke Of Edinburgh Stakes with Dash Of Spice.The four-year-old was the 7-2 favourite to follow up his emphatic victory at Epsom on Derby day three weeks ago and was well positioned throughout under the champion jockey.De Sousa - riding his second winner of the week - had made his challenge wide at the top of the home straight, but Dash Of Spice found plenty for pressure in the final furlong and ultimately won with something to spare.Sir Chauvelin ran a blinder to finish second ahead of Walton Street and Appeared.Earlier in the week, Ladies Day ended on a boozy note with punters flashing their pants and laying sprawled out on the ground.The raucous scenes - including crowds twerking to Beyonce track Single Ladies - came as a a horse pulling a carriage had to be put down after it was spooked and bolted in the town centre.The horse was one of a pair pulling a traditional coaching carriage when it slipped on the road surface at a roundabout on the High Street.Eyewitnesses said the horses careered into a shop window throwing the driver and several people off the high sided carriage.It came as a Royal footman took an almighty tumble from his horse as racegoers arrived.He fell in the Parade Ring during the carriage procession as Her Majesty the Queen made her entry.Her Majesty was later seen presenting the coveted Gold Cup to veteran jockey Frankie Dettori, who was at his racing best on the 7-4 joint favourite Stradivarius.It was the 47-year-old jockeys sixth Gold Cup win and he treated the 70,000 crowd to a trademark flying dismount.Love Islands Olivia Attwood was spotted celebrating a win alongside Charlie Frederick, who was recently booted off the show, and reality star Pete Wicks.The opening day saw Meghan Markle make her first visit to the racecourse.Husband Harry looked less than impressed when cheeky jockey Frankie Dettori planted a kiss on her hand.

title: the sun says theresa may brexit bold move
story: So much damage has been done to Britain since June 23, 2016 — not by the vote, but by the refusal of hardcore Remainers to accept it.They are not of course to blame for all the chaos. It is staggering that the ­Government is still undecided on ­fundamental principles.But the Tories’ woes were hugely exacerbated by their election calamity, caused in part by Remainers hoping Labour would betray Brexit.That emboldened diehards in the Lords and Commons — operating alongside the lavishly-funded, slickly orchestrated campaign colluding with Brussels to annul the biggest vote in our history.Meanwhile the national conversation has degenerated into a tsunami of hate, chiefly from sanctimonious Remainers branding Leavers uneducated racists.How much better off we would all now be if on June 24, 2016 they had grudgingly accepted defeat and pledged instead to make the best of Brexit.In fairness, some Remainers did. TV’s Richard Madeley spoke for them recently when he said we now had a duty to see it through in full by leaving the single market and customs union.He was right. To pretend that Brexit can be “softened” to honour the substantial Remain vote — a nightmarish fudge which Boris Johnson warns of today — is simply dishonest. There is leaving and there is remaining. That’s it.Brussels has revelled in Britain tearing itself apart. Now it is sidetracked by its own problems. A deal looks miles off.Theresa May has only one path forward. At next month’s pivotal vote, she must defeat the backbench rebellion hoping to shackle us to a customs union restricting our trading future. That is not Brexit, as voters would quickly realise. It would reignite the Leave ­campaign with unprecedented ferocity.And the PM and her Cabinet must not be derailed by Remain-fanatic businesses muttering about pulling out. Previous such threats have proved bogus, like all those dire economic forecasts.Leaving may not be smooth in the short-term. That must not deter us.When the EU finally realises Brexit in full is inevitable maybe they will stop playing games and agree a deal.But if the Remain resistance succeeds in crippling Brexit, it will bring on chaos.Our current divisions will seem like happy hour. And it will be their fault.HEARTBREAKING, isn’t it, to see Argentina in disarray and the Germans wobbling at the World Cup? We’re just about managing to keep our chins up.Let’s hope Harry Kane and our boys can show them how it’s done tomorrow.Do us proud, lads!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government end late payments to firms
story: It is a major victory for hundreds of thousands of small businesses who are crippled by big firms who pay suppliers late.The crackdown comes after The Sun revealed that nine in ten firms who supply government infrastructure projects are paid late.The research, released by the Federation of Small Businesses, follows the collapse of giant government supplier Carillion.Its collapse exposed how mega-firms cripple small businesses with a policy of making them wait 120 days before being paid.And it left small firms out of pocket and the taxpayer a whopping £148million bill.FSB chief Mike Cherry said the Government could free up billions of pounds by overhauling the way contracts are handed out.Current rules lock out cheaper small firms - effectively giving the major construction companies carte blanche to charge whatever they like for public infrastructure projects.Cabinet Office Minister Oliver Dowden last night promised to consider a raft of measures proposed by the FSB that would split up mega contracts and stop huge suppliers who pay late from getting any government work.The organisation said it would free up money for frontline services such as the NHS.Mr Cherry said: “The government wastes billions of pounds when it buys from a handful of large companies.“Today we set out how to save taxpayer money and avoid another Carillion.”Pledging help for small firms crippled with late payments, Mr Dowden said: I welcome these ideas from the FSB. Small businesses are the backbone of the economy and I am determined to level the playing field for them to compete for government contracts.“I will further consider these proposals from the FSB as we move forward with this work. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government gets kids to run mile
story: The free 15 minute Daily Mile initiative - started in Scotland in 2012 with great success – comes as ministers bid to fulfil a pledge to half the number of obese children by 2030.Campaigners – including The Sun - have branded it a “silver bullet” for boosting health and have pushed for it to be rolled out across the country.Children will be asked to run or jog for 15mins every day in the playground daily come rain, hail or shine.The run does not replace other sports or PE classes and teachers can fit it in during the day whenever they like.A recent study looking at 400 pupils in two Scottish primary schools found the task had improved fitness “remarkably” and made kids leaner.The plan is part of the Government’s obesity strategy to be launched next week to stop us becoming the fattest population in Europe in a decade.Ministers will run a staggering seven public consultations in parallel over 12 weeks this summer on their obesity strategy across advertising, unhealthy BOGOF offers and a potential sugar tax on food like the one slapped on fizzy drinks.The plans could also see restrictions on junk food advertising on television before the 9pm watershed and a potential ban on cartoon characters promoting unhealthy food.Last night Tory MP Dr Sarah Wollaston praised the initiative saying it was a “really positive way of boosting activity, fitness and wellbeing”.Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt has described the Daily Mile as an “excellent initiative” including physical exercise in an “easy, inclusive and fun way”.More than 3,500 schools in 30 plus countries around the globe have taken up the idea since award-winning head teacher Elaine Wylie came up with it six years ago while working at St Ninian’s Primary in Stirling.Researchers compared almost children aged between 4 and 12 at two primary schools in Scotland - one where pupils were doing the Daily Mile, and one where they were not.The children wore accelerometers which recorded how much moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) they were undertaking every day, and how long they were sitting about for.They were measured for body fat and timed on their performance at a shuttle run.Researchers found the kids who were doing the Daily Mile were significantly healthier than those who were not.Schools will be encouraged to take up the practice but it will not be made compulsory.Last night Education Secretary Damian Hinds said: “The Sun are right to champion Initiatives like the Daily Mile which is a great way to encourage young people to get regular physical activity.“The government are investing £320million a year in the Sports Premium to encourage schools to ensure their pupils are active at least once a day.“I know many schools already do this and I’d like to see more and more do so.”TV shows are fuelling obesity by using tubby celebs, a study suggests.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: england support at world cup lowest for 30 years supporters group says
story: It comes amid the strained ties between the UK and Russian governments following the poisoning of Russian ex-spy Sergei Skripal in Salisbury in March.MPs also raised concerns of a repeat of the violence seen in Marseille before and after England's match against Russia at Euro 2016.But the FSF such "dire warnings" had yet to become a reality."Over the years, regular travellers with England have had good reason to become sceptical about some of the dire warnings about the fate that could befall us at the next tournament," it said."If all we were told had been true, we would have been murdered in townships in South Africa, beaten up by racist hooligans in Ukraine or robbed at gunpoint in Brazilian favelas."It turns out that a little bit of common sense and preparation has generally been enough to keep us safe."The FSF added: "The big majority of Russian people have been immensely friendly, generous and welcoming."England fans above all should know from bitter experience the price that can be paid for judging everybody on the behaviour of a minority."As well as fears about violence, the supporters' group also cited the long distances, high costs and unlikely holiday feel to many host cities as factors stopping fans from travelling."The only sad thing about the whole experience is that the numbers of England fans who have been here to enjoy it have been so low," the FSF said."We reckon it's been probably the lowest number of England fans at a World Cup game for 30 years." The FSF added that Russia was not a "traditional" family holiday destination."We know there are a lot of other reasons why a lot of people have chosen to support the team from back home - there's the distances, the cost of travel, the inescapable fact that Russia isn't really a traditional family holiday destination."It's nonetheless a shame that some fans have been deterred from coming here because of disproportionate hype about the hooligan threat or political tensions," it continued.

title: miss great britain to keep swimsuit category
story: The 2017 #MeToo campaign against sexual harassment which started in Hollywood has led to a greater scrutiny of the objectification of women across the globe.Earlier this year, F1 racing decided it would no longer use promotion women, known as grid girls. Similarly, the British Professional Darts Corporation stopped using "walk-on-girls" as player escorts.But the decision by Miss Great Britain to keep its round has been welcomed by some in the pageant industry.Poppy Haskell is Miss Swimwear UK. She says winning the contest, which involved her wearing a bikini in front of judges, has kick-started her career in modelling and promotions work."Women know exactly what they are going into," Miss Haskell told Sky News.Body image expert Natashe Devon told Sky News that where it can become a problem if these image promote one body-type as the ideal."If you are bombarded by unrealistic imagery of people who look unattainable, then it's going start to negatively affect your self-esteem," Ms Devon said."But if your body diverges from what we consider to be beautiful, if for example we have scars, or blemishes or stretch marks, you are representing something that is a little bit different, then it's been shown to have a positive impact on how people feel about themselves."That is what led one woman to create the a plus-size beauty pageant.Samantha Coote founded Miss British Beauty Curve, a pageant for women size 14 or over, after she felt unable to enter a traditional pageant because she was plus-size. story: We joined women practising their driving skills on a simulator.One told us: "I can go to work, I can go to the hospital, I can take my children to school. My life is better. title: swimsuit model contests empower women they must not be scrapped
story: When I was growing up it was never my intention to be a model. I studied journalism at university but I soon realised an office job was not my calling.My move into the modelling industry came out of the blue.I was 18 years old and performing in a ballet show when someone from an agency spotted me. It led to some part-time modelling work but I have to admit I wasn't making a lot of money.I first heard about Miss Swimsuit UK through a close friend who had entered in 2015.It opened up a lot of opportunities for her so, in 2017, I decided to take the plunge and give the competition a go.My fellow contestants were from all sorts of backgrounds and there were plenty of different personalities.One woman worked in the navy, another worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Some women were shy, others were more confident.I took part in catwalks, wearing different swimsuits and answered questions from a presenter to give an impression of my personality.For me, the competition was a way of showcasing my gym work and healthy eating. The whole event was a celebration of the female form and for all the contestants, the event was about empowering each other.I didn't feel I was being judged in a negative way. I found it very liberating being in a swimsuit and people had worked hard to be able to enter the competition.To be named the winner was incredible. It was a massive boost to my confidence and it turned out to be the catalyst for my modelling career, which went into overdrive.I'm now modelling all over the world and hoping to move into TV presenting and producing.My parents - who both have corporate jobs - are immensely proud of me and my boyfriend has always been extremely supportive.   You have to set boundaries and I said to him from the start: "This is my passion - take it or leave it."I feel like I've finally found my niche in the industry. Having curves is great for swimsuit modelling.I'm not skinny and tall like a fashion model and I would never work as a glamour model because I wouldn't ever pose naked.Unfortunately though I've had a few bad experiences in the industry.There have been instances where male photographers have tried push me further than I wanted to go. title: dwp slammed asking writer help
story: NewsDWP slammed for asking writer to help 'empower' women into paid work... without paying herAmber Massie-Blomfield hit out at the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) in an open e-mail that she posted on Twitter&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter18:38, 22 JUN 2018NewsAmber Massie-Blomfield hit out at the Department for Work and Pensions (Image: Rosie Powell)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA writer has blasted the government for asking her to promote a campaign all about helping people into paid work... without actually paying her. Amber Massie-Blomfield hit out at the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) in an open e-mail that she posted on Twitter. She was asked to be part of the Her Way campaign, which aims to showcase routes into employment and empower women to craft their own future in work. The campaign declares: Women are often caught up in conflicting messages about their work: they ‘can’t’ do certain jobs or reach certain job levels, but at the same time are told to aspire to ‘have it all’. But when she asked to be paid for this task, she was told: Unfortunately, we can’t pay contributors - but would see it taking only a few hours of your time.   In a pithy email reply, Amber wrote: You will no doubt appreciate the irony of the DWP asking me to work with you as a contributor in this way without being paid. As an employee of the DWP, how would you advise I pay my mortgage, make my pension contribution, or indeed, feed myself, during the time I spend working, free-of-charge, on your campaign? Should I ask one of my other clients to subsidise DWP's campaign, or perhaps subsidise it myself, from the lavish income my life as a freelance arts professional affords?

title: england team truly represented health
story: NewsIf England team truly represented health of the nation three of the 11 players would be clinically obeseShadow Health and Culture secretaries Jon Ashworth and Tom Watson lay bare state of the nation - where half of our children could be obese by 2020&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom WatsonJon Ashworth21:49, 22 JUN 2018NewsEngland would be carrying three overweight players (Image: AFP/Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf the England boys in Russia actually reflected the nation’s health, three of the 11 players on the pitch would be clinically obese and four more would be overweight. We are in the grip of a crisis in our health. Approximately 14 million adults are obese. Around 15 million more are overweight. Based on current trends half of our children will be obese by 2020. The national cost to the NHS is upwards of &pound5billion a year. The personal cost can be catastrophic, with increased risk of type 2 diabetes, cancer, strokes and mental health conditions. Two years ago, Theresa May flunked the opportunity to make a big intervention with her first obesity plan, which failed to tackle junk food advertising and instead relied on voluntary action by the food and drinks industry.  It also ducked the issue of cheap, unhealthy supermarket offers. What’s more the Government is making &pound800million cuts to public health budgets, which means councils are forced to cut support services to combat obesity. The whole approach has been a disaster. And next week we fear we will get the same again. This crisis won’t be solved by a silver bullet. It’s got to be a many-pronged approach. One of those prongs has to be advertising.  A recent study found that young people who saw a junk food ad every day were twice as likely to be obese as those that didn’t. We must find a way to deal with this. Recent reports have said the Government plans to ban junk food advertising on TV before 9pm but that won’t cut it. Our children don’t spend hours a day watching TV any more. They are on their phones, gaming or watching YouTube. Banning ads on TV and leaving the online world alone will just see junk food ads flooding to platforms which are much less regulated and much less responsible than broadcasters.  Frankly, that would be an analogue policy for a digital age. It’s not just on screens that kids are bombarded with advertising. It’s on the bus, on trains and on their walk to school. Junk food advertising is banned within 100m of schools in some places but a 100m blackout isn’t enough. The test for the Government’s strategy will be that it tackles junk food advertising across the board. It must also deal with the plague of buy-one, get-one free offers that are the bugbear of many parents. How often do you see children screaming for chocolate – egged on by in-your-face offers – at the supermarket till queue? Right now, you can’t go to a corner shop without being surrounded by World Cup branded sweets and crisps placed at a child’s eye level.  As the Mirror highlighted this week, the manufacturers say they are labelling their products more clearly but what child thinks of a small packet of sweets as con&shy&shytaining two or more servings? The time to ask the giant food conglomerates, the manufacturers and the retailers to put their houses in order has long passed. They have failed to show any responsibility for the health of the nation – the only responsibility they show is the one to supply their owners and shareholders with booming profits. The sugar tax – one of the only things the Labour Party will ever thank former Chancellor George Osborne for – shows intervention can force the industry to change. If the Government’s second chance strategy is to really make a difference it needs to think bigger – about extending that tax to confectionary and other snacks.

title: pay rise armed forces demanded
story: NewsPay rise for armed forces demanded by Labour's defence chief as Theresa May attacked for starving them of cashShadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith is expected to back Trident to quell fears over Jeremy Corbyn’s commitment to the Armed Forces&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor22:04, 22 JUN 2018NewsNia Griffith will demand more money for troops (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour's defence chief will demand a pay rise for troops as she bids to exploit Tory divisions and quell fears over Jeremy Corbyn’s commitment to the Armed Forces. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith is expected to back Trident, call for more money for the military and attack Theresa May for starving defence of cash when she addresses the Royal United Services Institute think tank on Monday. A source said: “In government the Tories have slashed defence spending, cut the size of the Army and are giving a raw deal to our servicemen and women. “Labour wants to see proper investment in defence and a decent pay rise for our men and women who have had to endure seven years of real terms pay cuts since 2010, despite rising rents in service accommodation and cuts to tax credits.”  The Prime Minister is under mounting pressure after she threw into doubt Britain’s status as a tier one military power. It is widely taken to mean a country which has a full spectrum of military capabilities, including nuclear weapons, special forces, a navy, army and air force capable of being deployed anywhere in the globe. She pointedly refuse to use the phrase when challenged this week, despite standing next to NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg in No 10. With the Army about 5,000 below its manpower target and repeated warnings about expensive equipment such as new stealth fighter jets and armoured vehicles widening the black hole in the defence budget, Labour believes the Tories are vulnerable over defence. This year’s Armed Forces Continuous Attitudes Survey, slipped out last month(MAY, revealed 35% of personnel are dissatisfied with Service life amid plunging morale.  Just 31% of troops are satisfied with their pay, a drop of 52% compared with when the Conservatives came to power in 2010. Ms Griffith’s speech to RUSI comes in the week of Armed Forces Day and ahead of next month’s(JULY) crunch NATO summit in Brussels where Donald Trump is expected to rap allies for failing to pump enough cash into their military. She was appointed to the tricky Shadow Defence Secretary post in October 2016 amid renewed scrutiny of Labour’s policies for the Armed Forces.

title: 11 best spots uk watch
story: Advertorial11 best spots in the UK to watch an amazing sunset this summerThis week marks the summer solstice – and is also the official start of summer. So what better time to explore the UK and take in some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides?&nbspShareByHolly Thatcher14:24, 22 JUN 2018Updated14:41, 22 JUN 2018Advertorial (Image: Getty)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe've been blessed with some decent weather already in 2018 - but this week is when summer *officially* begins. June 21, the summer solstice in the Northern Hemisphere, is the longest day in the year - affording us approximately 17 hours of daylight. Technically, this also means that the nights will start drawing in again now - so there's really no time like the present to get out and explore the great outdoors on some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides. We've taken a look around the UK to find the best places to watch the sun setting.  1. Museum of Scottish Lighthouses, Fraserburgh, Scotland   A small village called Maud in Aberdeenshire offers a starting place for a traffic-free cycle to the coast. If you're in the mood to learn then head to the Museum of Scottish Lighthouses in Fraserburgh. The sun will set at around 10.12pm this week in this part of Scotland, so you've got loads of time to enjoy the start of the summer.  Bike need replacing?       If your existing bike needs replacing, you'll want something efficient and speedy for the roads - like the Carrera Parva Hybrid bike , which comes in versions for both men and women and is now just &pound210 (a saving of &pound90).  And if you don't need a new bike, why not have yours checked over before setting off. Like any mode of transport your bike needs to be looked after and regularly checked for wear and tear.  Halfords offers a 32-point Free Bike Check which includes:   Frame, saddle and handlebar Wheels including tyres, rims, spokes and hubs Brake system including levers, calipers, pads and cables / hoses Drivetrain including gears, levers, chain, bottom bracket, cranks and cables   2. The Eden Project, Cornwall      Why not spend the day enjoying the amazing sights at the Eden Project? Best of all, if you arrive by bike you'll get a discount on entry. The sun sets on Eden at around 9:30pm on the solstice. Bear in mind though that the Eden Project shuts at 6pm, so you'll need to watch the sun go down somewhere nearby.   Get there in style on the Carrera Subway 1 Hybrid Bike , &pound300. With easy to use 24 speed Shimano gearing, your effort for building speed will be minimised on all terrains, while its lightweight aluminium frame means you can quickly and efficiently ride to your destination.   Camping out?      Planning to camp? Be sure you book in advance as you won't want to be without a pitch.  Croft Farm Holiday Park is just a mile from the Eden Project and three miles from the beach. Pentewan Sands is also nearby and boasts amazing family facilities - as well as the nearby Pentewan Cycle Trail.   Consider taking a Halfords Vis A Vis 4 Person Tent with you, which is currently reduced to just &pound60, (was &pound150, save &pound90). The simple tunnel design is easy to pitch in approximately 20 minutes. With two separate bedrooms and a living area, it's perfect for families or groups of friends.   For additional comfort pack an Urban Escape Folding Table And Bench Set , &pound40 (was &pound50, save &pound10) which folds down into a single carry case to make it easy to transport and store.      3. Pembrokeshire Coast National Park, Wales   The Pembrokeshire Coast Path is an absolutely beautiful part of Wales and a stunning place to watch the sun go down. There are loads of campsites in the area, including some unique places to stay. There are plenty of bike routes too, with some offering traffic-free options if you want a more peaceful ride. In Pembrokeshire you can expect the sun to set around 9:39pm.  Why not try..       The Boardman ADV 8.8 Adventure Bike , &pound750, is a bike truly made to help you explore new possibilities. This bike is adept at riding in comfort on roads but really excels when you want to get off the beaten track.         4. White Nancy, Cheshire      Located on Kerridge Hill, White Nancy is a local landmark from which you can see all around the area, from Wales to the west and the Pennines to the north. From time to time White Nancy is painted to look like other things, like a Christmas pudding or with Olympic rings when London hosted in 2012. The sun will set over White Nancy at around 9:36 this week.  Need to drive?     Heading further afield to enjoy the sunny days? If you're packing up the whole family into the car for a camping trip, make sure it's in good running order first.  A Free Car Check performed by Halfords experts will put your mind at rest. Book online or just pop in to your local Halfords store and trained colleagues will carry out a free car bulb check and check your battery, wiper blades, engine oil level and air conditioning, and check for any windscreen chips. They'll even give you a free screenwash top-up too.    If you're making an unfamiliar journey, don't forget to get the Garmin Drive Sat Nav , &pound79.99 (was &pound99.99, save &pound20.99). With lifetime map updates you're never going to find yourself driving down a newly-closed street or down a disused road.   5. Edinburgh Castle, Scotland   There are few places that are as stunning as Edinburgh Castle, located atop Castle Rock. The views of Edinburgh from the castle are amazing, and a great place to watch the end of the day roll around. Sunset here will take place at 9:58pm.  6. Hampstead Heath, London   The scenery on Hampstead Heath always pleases the eye. This amazing part of London has views of every landmark you could hope for and it's a wonderful place to watch the sun go down. This will happen at around 9:18pm in the capital.        7. Osborne House, Isle of Wight      The home of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert is quite a sight to see. Accessible by bike (and ferry, if you're not an island resident), it's the ideal place to see during the day before you settle down somewhere to watch the sunset. If you're up for the cycle, Shanklin Chine on the west of the island is well worth an evening visit.   Do it with ease - and classic style - on the Pendleton Somerby Electric Hybrid Bike , &pound750. title: abusive boyfriend made partner massage
story: NewsAbusive boyfriend made partner massage his hands after beating her because injuries ruined his workoutAuzair Hussain, 24, stopped his girlfriend from laughing, told her what she could eat, whipped her with a belt and prevented her from contacting friends and family&nbspShareByPhilip DeweyLucy Clarke-Billings17:11, 22 JUN 2018Updated17:15, 22 JUN 2018NewsHussain was convicted of coercive and controlling behaviour and assault occasioning ABH (Image: South Wales Police)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn abusive boyfriend made his partner massage his hands after he beat her because the pain affected his ability to bench press. Auzair Hussain reduced his girlfriend to a shadow of herself during a campaign to control her while they were both students at Cardiff politan University. From January to March last year, 24-year-old Hussain assaulted the French national on numerous occasions and whipped her with a belt and coat hanger. He controlled a number of aspects of his girlfriend’s life including the clothes and make-up she wore, what she ate, when she could shower, and who she was allowed to speak to while he also prevented her from speaking in her mother tongue and from contacting friends and family. He also hated her laughing and made her be quiet when she was in his presence.  A sentencing hearing at Newport Crown Court on Friday heard Hussain first attacked his victim after he saw her smoking a cigarette and she declined to hold his hand in public. It was at this stage he used the belt and hanger to whip his girlfriend, including her chest and private areas. On another occasion, after she looked at a LinkedIn account of a former boyfriend, Hussain threw her about, punched and kicked her, and strangled her before trashing her room. He told his terrified victim – who feared for her life and was so scared she wet herself – he would not hit her in the head because the head is for slapping. After another argument was started by the defendant, he punched and kicked his girlfriend and forced her to strip naked.  Straight after the assault Hussain went to the gym but complained his bench pressing had been affected by hand injuries sustained during the beating. She was later forced to massage his hands to soothe his injuries. Hussain, of Birmingham, was later convicted of coercive and controlling behaviour and assault occasioning ABH and he pleaded guilty to a count of assault occasioning ABH. In a statement read out to the court by prosecutor Sarah Waters, his victim said she felt destroyed as a person as a result of the relationship in which she felt trapped. She described the defendant as being extreme in everything he did and of pushing her beyond her boundaries. She said: I think it’s difficult for anyone who has not been in a controlling relationship to understand why I stayed with him but retrospectively I hate myself for being a coward and not running away. What should have been one of the best years of my life studying abroad turned into a nightmare.

story: NewsFormer Royal Navy officer who groped junior crew member jailed for more than seven yearsCharles Howeson, 69, was convicted of 10 indecent assaults against eight young men in the 1980s and 1990s&nbspShareByClaire Hayhurst22:07, 22 JUN 2018Updated22:23, 22 JUN 2018NewsDisgraced former Royal Navy officer Charles Howeson was convicted of 10 indecent assaults against eight young men in the 1980s and 1990s (Image: Plymouth Herald / SWNS)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former commander in the Royal Navy and former senior member of staff at Coutts has been jailed for seven years and six months for indecently assaulting eight young men. Charles Howeson, 68, used his qualities, advantages and power to act as a sexual predator towards young men while in three separate roles between 1985 and 1994. He was convicted of 10 indecent assaults against eight young men during that period, following a trial at Bristol Crown Court last year. The court heard he was the effective captain of HMS Cleopatra in 1985 and groped a junior member of crew on an unlit deck. A Royal Navy inquiry was launched after the victim, and a second man who reported Howeson for touching his stomach and tugging at his shirt, complained. Judge Mark Horton said senior officers associated with Howeson effectively closed ranks and put his interests, and the reputation of the Navy, above those whom it should have been protecting. Howeson was given a formal warning by the Royal Navy and never commanded a ship of the fleet again - though was promoted - and retired in 1990.  He then worked as a chief executive at a charity in Plymouth, where he indecently assaulted six volunteers in dark tunnels on Drake's Island and dark rooms. Complaints were made but the allegations were not reported to police to save the reputation of the trust, the judge said, and Howeson was allowed to resign. Following his resignation, Howeson saw a further opportunity to manipulate and assault another young man. The judge ordered Howeson, of Craigie Drive, Plymouth, to pay prosecution costs of &pound50,000 and sign the sex offenders register indefinitely. This case has revealed that to the outside world you displayed the finest qualities of diplomacy, charisma, endeavour, organisation and charm which you demonstrated during your period in the Navy and in your extensive and successful career and involvement at the very highest level with public bodies, authorities, businesses including a bank but also in your public and charitable works mainly associated with the community of Plymouth, the judge told Howeson. The hidden and dark truth is these same qualities were the very qualities which enabled you to mask and conceal a dark secret only revealed for the world to see some 30 years later in this trial. That secret was your uncontrolled and predatory sexual behaviour particularly towards young or at least vulnerable men under your control. Between 1985 and 1994, in three separate roles in your professional life, you used all of your qualities, advantages and power to use and abuse your position to enable you to act as a sexual predator. In most cases you effectively trapped them like prey in order to abuse them.
